name: Infinity and beyond
description: The constantly evolving characters in Infinity are created through procedural generation, a technique that creates special effects, characters, videogame levels and sound via a set of algorithms, predefined rules or data inputs.

key_work.title: Infinity
key_work.brief_description:
Did you catch the parade of fantastical creatures behind you?

Be quick! Once they’ve run, hopped and stumbled across the screen, you won’t see them again. This artwork is being created live and each character is unique. These hypnotic beings are born from code through a process known as ‘procedural generation’.

Procedural generation is often used in videogames to create animated characters, digital landscapes, textures, and even sound effects – all in real time. Universal Everything (UE) used motion-capture technology and CGI (computer-generated imagery) to create a suite of character models. They then established a set of rules to determine how colour, texture and shape could be combined before an algorithm was programmed to randomly select combinations. This generates infinite variations in the characters you meet on screen.

Universal Everything see this creative process as a collaboration between humans and computers. What’s fun about the method is that not even UE know who the computer might create next!

Creative Director: Matt Pyke
Executive Producer: Claire Spencer Cook
Design and Unity Development: Adam Samson
Sound Design: Simon Pyke
Studio Technician: Spike Thompson

end.title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
end.creator_credit: Barrie M. Osborne, Fran Walsh and Peter Jackson
end.headline_credit: New Zealand and United States of America, 2002

video_links.name: The Two Towers | The Lord of the Rings 4K Ultra HD | Warner Bros. Entertainment

end.brief_description: Frodo and Sam trek to Mordor to destroy the One Ring of Power while Gimli, Legolas and Aragorn search for the orc-captured Merry and Pippin. All along, nefarious wizard Saruman awaits the Fellowship members at the Orthanc Tower in Isengard.

constellations_other.name: The forest for the trees
constellations_other.description: Marshmallow Laser Feast's Sanctuary of the Unseen Forest celebrates the majestic Colombian kapok tree. Let's look back at some of screen culture's other mighty trees and forests.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_other.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

links.description: The endless procession of characters in Infinity are created with procedural generation. Stephen Regelous at Weta Digital pioneered using procedural generation in film in The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers, using AI and CGI armies in the film’s epic set piece.

links.description: Ever seen TikTok videos that pit 10,000 orcs against 2,000 Jedi? These epic battle simulations are made with the same kind of procedural technology at The Two Towers and like many Universal Everything works it was made with game engine Unity.

end.title: Game of Thrones
end.creator_credit: Christopher Newman, Duncan Muggoch, Greg Spence, Lisa McAtackney, Devin Stoutley, Paul Zeke and Shaila Tobin

video_links.name: Game of Thrones | Season 1 | Official Trailer

end.brief_description: Seven noble families fight for control of the mythical land of Westeros. Friction between the houses leads to full-scale war. All while a very ancient evil awakens in the farthest north. Amidst the war, a neglected military order of misfits, the Night’s Watch, is all that stands between the realms of men and icy horrors beyond.

constellations_other.name: The Hatfield House rules
constellations_other.description: The shooting location of The Favourite, Hatfield House, has appeared in a number of other iconic works.

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

constellations_other.name: Significant sounds
constellations_other.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

links.description: The VFX artists who worked on the Battle of Helm’s Deep were still at Weta when the company made Game of Thrones’ Battle of Winterfell, which was itself inspired by Helm’s Deep.

end.title: Tribes
end.material_description: Single-channel video installation, stereo sound/ Duration: 05:35mins, looped
end.brief_description:
Are there patterns in the way we move?

In Tribes, thousands of people flow, follow and form in sync, creating connections and collective patterns that hint at common goals. If we zoom out and look down, these human figures become a fluid stream of colour and movement, a living artwork that reveals the invisible design in the crowd’s behaviour.

For this work, Universal Everything (UE) referenced crowd-simulation software, which typically predicts the flow of people through airports or sports stadiums. Here, it reflects UE’s curiosity about choreography and the rules of human behaviour. Aerial photography and fluid dynamics simulations also inspired these hypnotic compositions, which were animated using Houdini.

Although made using modern software, the tribal chanting in the soundtrack connects us to the past, asking us to think about how a crowd reveals the universality of humanity.

Creative Director: Matt Pyke, Mike Hughes
Senior Producer: Greg Povey
Animator: Chris Perry
Sound Design: Simon Pyke

Commissioned by the Borusan Contemporary, Istanbul

constellations_other.name: Infinity and beyond

links.description: Universal Everything’s Tribes is made using crowd control software that UE have put certain parameters in to create the artworks people see. Crowd simulation software is part of what animates Epic Battle Simulator.

end.title: No Man's Sky
end.brief_description: Inspired by the adventure and imagination that we love from classic science-fiction, No Man’s Sky presents you with a galaxy to explore, filled with unique planets and lifeforms, and constant danger and action.

constellations_other.name: Superhero special effects
constellations_other.description: VFX talent isn't limited to just one studio that makes superhero blockbusters.

links.description: Perhaps the most famous videogame to use procedural generation is No Man’s Sky. Each planet, creature, ship and other items are created procedurally using algorithms and it was hyped for its ever-changing worlds and stories, which were also procedurally generated.

end.title: Elite
end.brief_description:
Elite is a space trading video game, written and developed by David Braben and Ian Bell and originally published by Acornsoft for the BBC Micro and Acorn Electron computers in September 1984.Elite’s open-ended game model, and revolutionary 3D graphics led to it being ported to virtually every contemporary home computer system, and earned it a place as a classic and a genre maker in gaming history. The game’s title derives from one of the player’s goals of raising their combat rating to the exalted heights of “Elite”.

Elite was one of the first home computer games to use wire-frame 3D graphics with hidden line removal. It added graphics and twitch gameplay aspects to the genre established by the 1974 game Star Trader. Another novelty was the inclusion of The Dark Wheel, a novella by Robert Holdstock which gave players insight into the moral and legal codes to which they might aspire.

constellations_other.name: Infinity and beyond
constellations_other.description: The constantly evolving characters in Infinity are created through procedural generation, a technique that creates special effects, characters, videogame levels and sound via a set of algorithms, predefined rules or data inputs.

links.description: While procedural generation might seem like cutting-edge technology, it’s been used in computer games since 1984’s Elite, which, like No Man’s Sky, used computer algorithms to create the planets in its eight galaxies.
